{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Challenge to the basic foundations of British rule", "Description": "The sepoys in 1857 challenged the legitimacy of British rule in at least the northern part of India. This was a challenge to the basic foundations of British rule. The sepoys were in a state of frenzy and brooked no opposition. The sepoys were asserting their right to elect their own officers and revived old practices such as the 'panch' or panchayat. The sepoys had resentment against their native officers who on the face of it were at the mercy of the sepoys. The sepoys had a strong streak of defiance and assertion.", "Participants/People": ["sepoys"], "Location": "India", "Place": null, "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": null, "Key Details": null, "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Sepoys interrupting Maharaja", "Description": "The revolt of the sepoys, led by Scindia, envisaged resentment against their native officers who sided with the European officers in clamping down on cases of day-to-day dissent.", "Participants/People": ["Scindia", "officers", "sepoys"], "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": "Native officers sided with European officers in suppressing sepoys' dissent.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "Sepoys demanding Agra capture", "Description": "The revolt of the sepoys also seemed to envisage in its vision, resentment against their native officers who on the face of it were at the mercy of the sepoys. Possibly the sepoys had resented the fact that the native officers invariably sided with the European officers in clamping down on cases of day-to-day dissent. Native officers had a curiously dichotomous attitude. Previous localised mutinies had often found the native officers acquiescing in the revolt of the sepoys or in certain instances providing the lead to the revolt though, as mentioned before, the native officer sided with the authorities when it came to stamping out cases of day-to-day dissent by sepoys. 1857 was different in the sense it was the average sepoy who held sway. The rebellion was a manifestation of his multifold resentment, which enveloped in its anger multiple layers of hierarchy. No figure was hallowed for them, the sepoy's anger and arrogance would not spare even the emperor. There were reports that the sepoys, clamouring to be paid, addressed the Mughal emperor in disrespectful terms ('Ari Badshah' or even 'Ari Buddha'). Some were bold enough to pull him by the hand while one apparently tugged his beard asking him to listen. The sepoys even possessed the audacity to demand the queen Zeenat Mahal as a hostage since they suspected her along with Bahadur Shah's physician Ahsanullah Khan of being in league with the British.", "Participants/People": ["sepoys"], "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": "Sepoys demanding Agra capture", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "Sepoys disrespecting Maharaja", "Description": "The sepoys were hardly respectful in their attitude towards Scindia. Their tone towards him was peremptory; they were attempting to dictate terms to him. While they did not attempt to totally cast aside his authority, they would accept his nominal suzerainty on their own terms. Times had changed at least temporarily. The traditional elite could no longer hope to command without their power being questioned and challenged.", "Participants/People": ["sepoys"], "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": "Sepoys disrespecting Maharaja", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "1857 Revolt", "Description": "The 1857 Revolt, also known as the First War of Indian Independence, was a large-scale uprising in India against British rule. It was led by Indian revolutionaries, including Rani Lakshmibai and Jhalkari Bai, who fought against the British for freedom and independence. The revolt was fueled by a combination of factors, including the perceived oppression of the Indian people by British rule, the introduction of new rules and policies, and a desire for self-governance. The revolt lasted for several months and involved numerous battles and skirmishes across India. Ultimately, the British were able to suppress the rebellion, but the revolt had a lasting impact on Indian history and the struggle for independence.", "Participants/People": ["Rani Lakshmibai", "Jhalkari Bai"], "Location": "India", "Place": "Various locations across India", "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": "1858", "Key Details": "The revolt was sparked by the perceived oppression of the Indian people, the introduction of new rules and policies, and a desire for self-governance.", "Day": "00", "Month": "00", "Year": "00", "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "Uda Devi's Leadership in Women's Army", "Description": "Uda Devi, also known as Jagrani, was a key figure in the 1857 Revolt. She formed a women's army, with herself as the commander, to fight against the British during their attack on Lucknow under Campbell. Her husband, Makka Pasi, became a martyr in the battle at Chinhat, and Uda Devi took revenge by leading her army in battle against the British. Her women's army consisted of dalit women, who were considered untouchable by some and weak by others. {"Events": [{"Event Name": "Trial Scene", "Description": "In the \"trial scene\" towards the end of the novel, Seeta, Cyril, and Grace find themselves in a temple on a hill, on the side of which a river runs. Seeta is engaged in an act of worship, and Cyril and Grace admire the prospect by picturesque gazing and sketching. It is only the latter two who are able to \"properly appreciate\" the land: Seeta, herself, is engaged in quite another act, and when she does cease worshipping, she becomes the subject of Grace's sketch that Cyril completes. The connection between visual purchase of and actual proprietary claim over the land is made in this incident.", "Participants/People": ["Seeta", "Cyril", "Grace"], "Location": "temple on a hill", "Place": "hills", "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": null, "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Mangal Pandey's Rebellion", "Description": "Mangal Pandey led a rebellion against British colonial rule in India during the Indian Rebellion of 1857. He was a sepoy in the British East India Company's army. He is known for his actions on 29 April 1857, when he refused to accept new rifle cartridges that were greased with beef or pork, which violated his religious beliefs. This led to his subsequent arrest, trial, and execution. Mangal Pandey is considered a symbol of resistance against colonial rule in India.", "Participants/People": ["Mangal Pandey"], "Location": "British East India Company's army", "Place": "India", "Start Date": "29 April 1857", "End Date": "29 April 1857", "Key Details": "Rebellion against British colonial rule; refusal to use greased cartridges violating religious beliefs; execution", "Day": "29", "Month": "04", "Year": "1857", "General Comments": null}]}
